html:
Latin Wikipedia has an article on:
crux
Wikipedia la

Etymology[edit]

From Proto-Indo-European *(s)ker- (“to turn, to bend”).[1] Possible cognate with Latin circus (“circle”) and curvus (“curve”).

Pronunciation[edit]

  • (Classical) IPA(key): /kruks/, [krʊks]
  • (Ecclesiastical) IPA(key): /kruks/
  • Audio (Classical)
    		(file)

Noun[edit]

crux f (genitive crucis); third declension

  1. wooden frame on which criminals were crucified, especially a cross
  2. (derogatory) gallows bird; one who deserves to be hanged
  3. (figuratively) torture; misery

Declension[edit]

Third-declension noun.

Case Singular Plural
Nominative crux crucēs
Genitive crucis crucum
Dative crucī crucibus
Accusative crucem crucēs
Ablative cruce crucibus
Vocative crux crucēs

Derived terms[edit]

  • cruciārius
  • crucifer
  • crucifīgō
  • crucifixor
  • cruciō

Related terms[edit]

  • cruciābilis
  • cruciābiliter
  • cruciābilitās
  • cruciābundus
  • cruciāmen
  • cruciāmentum
  • cruciātiō
  • cruciātor
  • cruciātōrius
  • cruciātus

Descendants[edit]

  • Aromanian: crutsi, crutse, crutsã
  • Corsican: croce, croci
  • Dalmatian: crauc
  • Franco-Provençal: croués
  • Friulian: crôs
  • Italian: croce
  • Mozarabic:
    Arabic: كْروشّى‎ (kruši)
    Hebrew: כרושׁיִ‎ (kruši)
  • Old French: crois
    • Bourbonnais-Berrichon: queroix, queroué
    • Middle French: croix, crois
      • French: croix
        • Haitian Creole: kwa
    • Picard: croé
    • Norman: crouaix (Jersey), croués (France), kérouaïe (Guernsey), krwee (Sark)
    • Tourangeau: crouéx
    • Walloon: croes
  • Old Leonese:
    • Asturian: cruz
  • Old Occitan:
    • Catalan: creu
    • Occitan: crotz
  • Old Portuguese: cruz
    • Galician: cruz
    • Portuguese: cruz
      • Kabuverdianu: krus
      • Papiamentu: krus
  • Old Spanish:
    • Spanish: cruz
      • → Southeastern Tepehuan: kuruus
      • → Tagalog: krus
  • Romanian: cruce
  • Romansch: crusch, crousch
  • Sardinian: cruche, crugi, cruxi, gruche, grughe, gruxi
  • Sicilian: cruci
  • Venetian: cróxe
  • → Albanian: kryq
  • → English: crux
    • → French: crux
  • → Dutch: crux
  • → German: Crux
  • → Icelandic: krús
  • → Middle Dutch: cruce
    • Dutch: kruis
      • Afrikaans: kruis
    • Limburgish: kruutse
    • West Flemish: kruus
  • → Old English: crūċ
    • Middle English: crouche, cruche
      • English: crouch
  • → Old High German: krūzi, chrūzi
    • Middle High German: kriuz, kriuze
      • Alemannic German: Chrüüz
      • Central Franconian: Krütz, Krüz, Kreiz
        Hunsrik: Kreiz
        Luxembourgish: Kräiz
      • East Central German: Greiz, Greize
        Vilamovian: krojc
      • German: Kreuz
      • Rhine Franconian:
        Pennsylvania German: Greiz
  • → Old Irish: croch
    • Irish: croch
    • Scottish Gaelic: croch
  • → Old Irish: cros
    • Irish: cros
    • Scottish Gaelic: crois
    • → Old Norse: kross
      • Faroese: kross
      • Icelandic: kross
      • → Old English: cros
        • → Middle English: cross, cros, croz, crosse, crosce
          • English: cross
            • → Japanese: クロス (kurosu)
          • Scots: cross, cros
  • → Brythonic: croes
    • Welsh: croes
    • Cornish: krows
    • Breton: kroes, kroaz
  • → Old Saxon: krūci
    • Middle Low German: kruze, kruce
      • Dutch Low Saxon: kruus
      • German Low German: Krüüz, Kriiz
        • Plautdietsch: Kjriez
      • → Danish: kryds
      • → Norwegian: kryss
      • → Swedish: kryss

The intermediate steps of the following borrowings are undetermined. They are organized into groups that may be from the same source.

  • Frisian:
    • → Saterland Frisian: Krüüs
    • → West Frisian: krús
  • Scandinavian:
    • → Danish: kors
    • → Norwegian: kors
    • → Swedish: kors
  • Slavic:
    • → Belarusian: крыж (kryž)
    • → Czech: kříž
    • → Polish: krzyż
      • → Lithuanian: kryžius
    • → Serbo-Croatian:
      Cyrillic: криж
      Latin: križ
    • → Slovak: kríž
    • → Slovene: križ
    • → Upper Sorbian: křiž
  • South Asian:
    • → Bengali: ক্রুশ (kruś)
    • → Hindi: क्रूश (krūś)
    • → Malayalam: കുരിശ് (kuriśŭ)
    • → Sinhalese: කුරුසය (kurusaya)
  •  ?
    • → Basque: gurutze

References[edit]

  • crux in Charlton T. Lewis and Charles Short (1879) A Latin Dictionary, Oxford: Clarendon Press
  • crux in Charlton T. Lewis (1891) An Elementary Latin Dictionary, New York: Harper & Brothers
  • crux in Charles du Fresne du Cange’s Glossarium Mediæ et Infimæ Latinitatis (augmented edition, 1883–1887)
  • crux in Gaffiot, Félix (1934) Dictionnaire Illustré Latin-Français, Hachette
  • Carl Meissner; Henry William Auden (1894) Latin Phrase-Book‎[2], London: Macmillan and Co.
    • to threaten some one with death, crucifixion, torture, war: minitari (minari) alicui mortem, crucem et tormenta, bellum
    • to crucify: in crucem agere, tollere aliquem
    • to crucify: cruci suffigere aliquem
  • crux in Harry Thurston Peck, editor (1898) Harper's Dictionary of Classical Antiquities, New York: Harper & Brothers
  • crux in William Smith et al., editor (1890) A Dictionary of Greek and Roman Antiquities, London: William Wayte. G. E. Marindin
